instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.C7125: What is C7125? Capacitor between CHGR_BOOT and CHGR_PHASE important for bootstrapping creation of PPBUS_G3H on 2013-2015 macbook pros.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
Hi,

Need help with a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board. Green light and then goes amber but no fan spin. I checked all power rails and found <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> missing. I followed louis’ video [MEDIA=vimeo]315832835[/MEDIA] and as correctly pointed out <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> missing. Checked the link from <RESISTOR>R6125</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R6012</RESISTOR> to test point and test point to <RESISTOR>R1548</RESISTOR> and they are just fine. So what next. Is it the bios or CPU. Any further suggestions..

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Do not suspect BIOS, untill power on sequence is completed.
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

Post <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> at same time.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> – 3.3 v
<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> – 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> – 2.07v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> – 3.41v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> – 3.3 v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> – 2.3 mv
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> – 1.4 v
Sorry i don't have a scope and can't check for pulse at  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
You don't need an o-scope to see if a voltage tries to appear, or not.
However, is not the case here, as you are missing previous signals required.

Check for corrosion around <CHIP>U8130</CHIP>.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R8133</RESISTOR> is good.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message: Checked <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> and seems clean. <RESISTOR>R8133</RESISTOR> measures 99.2k. This board has no history of water damage and is pretty clean.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
Check if <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> goes high removing <CHIP>U8130</CHIP>.
If yes, change it...

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message: Removed <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> and  <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> still shows 720 mv and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> also dropped to 1.41v.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
<CHIP>U8130</CHIP> cannot drop <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Check what happen with this voltage...

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
Will need help sorting this. 
F7140 - 1.4v on both sides.
<RESISTOR>R7185</RESISTOR> - 16.5v on pin 1 and  6.36v on pin2.
<RESISTOR>R7186</RESISTOR> - 6.36v on pin1 and 3.7mv on pin2.
Looking for further guidance.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
If you had <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> in the first post, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was good.
Something happened when you've changed the <CHIP>U8130</CHIP>.

Check for short on all big coils.
Post diode mode to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
And basic voltages for <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>; pins 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17, 19, 20, 27.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message: Please correct me if I am wrong.. you want the above readings with <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> off the board or should I solder it back on the board and then give you the readings. This reading of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is with <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> off the board.I have not changed <CHIP>U8130</CHIP>. I removed <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> and checked <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> for high as instructed and I happened to check <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and it showed 1.4v. Sorry for the long post but I am a little confused here....

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
No matters <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> is soldered, or not.
You must get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> in both cases...

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
Reading as requested with <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> not soldered.

Check for short on all big coils – No short on any coils.
Post diode mode to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. – 2.378
And basic voltages for <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>;

pins
1 - 3.9mv
2 - 16.29v
3 - 4.28v
9 - 0.38mv
12 - 3.41v
13 - 2.95v
14 - 3.13v
15 - 57.3mv
17 - 1.41v
19 - 5.1v
20 - 5.1v
27 – 16.1v

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
Something happened when you've removed <CHIP>U8130</CHIP>.
It is far away of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, I have no idea what else you've touched.

Change <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>.

"diode mode to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. – 2.378"
This doesn't look like diode mode.
Keep in mind, ALWAYS measure diode mode with red probe on ground.
Sometime need to invert the leads too.
You should get 0.100-150 and OL for black on ground.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message: Diode mode red to ground i get 0.137 and black to ground i get 2.378.

threads.message:

???

Also check all traces and solders around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message: Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> and I got 3.9v on F7140 and no fan spin. Second time i switched on i get a fan spin. I installed the heat sink and powered up again. Fan spin and <CAPACITOR>C7370</CAPACITOR> just blew up. Any checks before i replace it and switch on.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
Probably <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> shorted between <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR> and L7130.
Replace <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> and assure good solders at <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message: Replaced <CAPACITOR>C7370</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR>. <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> traces seem to be visually all fine. Resoldered <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>. Should i change <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> again before I power on?

threads.message:
Powered on but no fan spin and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> missing. Changed <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> and still missing. So i decided to check all voltages again and <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> also missing.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 120 mv

<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> – 3.3 v
<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> – 1.6 mv
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> – 586 mv
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> – 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> – 3.1v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> – 2.3 mv
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> – 1.4 v

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
I'm wonder why do you check secondary voltages derived from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, when this is missing...

Post <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> basic voltages; pins 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17, 19, 20, 27.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
"L7030 to Ground – 00.40 Ohms"
Do you mean 400 miliohm?
That is pure short and seems to be safe to inject voltage.
1-2V should be good enough to find the culprit; maybe just a capacitor.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message: Applied 2v and it draws 5.2 amp current but nothing blows up or heats up. Checked on both sides of the board. Nothing..

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
Do you have 5A lab PSU?
In such case, it doesn't inject anything; in fact, got blocked.
Lower the voltage to maintain curent under PSU limit.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
Do you get VCORE?
Check all coils voltage and pages 57/58.

Try to start in SMC bypass also.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
No need to check any S3/0 voltage, as you don't get L7520 voltage (5V).

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
Sorry but you'll have to guide me thru this one.. please tell me the procedure. How do i trigger  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and can i check for drop pulse with a multi meter?
 I just checked voltage on L7520 when i power on. it gives me 5.1v when fan spins and then drops again 5.1v fan spins and drops. 
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> has 3.41v.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
As you must work with board alone on the desk, <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads can be used instead od power button.
In fact, solder a wire on a convenient point of <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and temporary touch the ground, simulating power button action.
Voltmeter should note <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> dropping from 3V to 0V at same time.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message: Appreciate you hand holding me thru this one... Did as instructed and  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>  drops from 3.4v to 0v. Fan spins and stops.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
If fan spins, this means the board tries to start at least.
Check if voltage appears on all big coils at that time.
Also try to start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message: Like i mentioned in my earlier post ....  I just checked voltage on L7520 when i power on. it gives me 5.1v when fan spins and then drops again 5.1v fan spins and drops.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
"Check if voltage appears [U][B]on all big coils[/B][/U] at that time."
Did you really check for pulse at ALL big coils???

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
L7130 - 8.59v steady
L7520 - 5.1v and drops
L7560 - 3.3v steady
L7430 - 1.21v and drops
L7630 - 1.05v and drops
L7310 - 1.8v and drops
L7320 - 1.8v and drops
SMC bypass - Fan spins, all voltages steady and i get display too.  What next..

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message:
That means you have problem with some SMC sensor level.
Check the pages 41/42.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message: Removed and re soldered <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and I have a perfect working board. Boots up and working fine on adapter but randomly shuts down when running on battery. Sometimes works for 5 minutes and sometimes just shuts down before the boot process completes. No problems when it's running on adapter.  Any ideas what i should check?

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message: First step, try known good battery.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message: Battery change Done. SMC Reset done. PRAM reset done.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message: Start in SMC bypass, disconnect charger and check if still turns off with battery alone.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message: How can i confirm if it has started in smc bypass. I keep the power button pressed for 10 seconds but it boots up and behaves like it is normal. I read it becomes slow but i don't feel any difference.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message: Fan must start with full speed in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message: This one is driving me crazy... I keep the power button pressed for 10 - 15 seconds but find no change in fan speed. I am not sure if i managed to do a smc bypass. I still shuts down on battery. will run for maybe a few minutes. Any other way to do a smc bypass?

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message: Try first without battery, to be sure if goes in SMC bypass mode correctly.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message: Without battery, with battery but still no luck. Fan spins at about 2500 RPM. Let me clarify one thing... I keep the power button pressed for 10 -20 seconds to get in to SMC bypass mode. Is that the correct and only way? Anything else i can check for this random shutdown on battery?

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Fan Spin.
threads.message: If you really enter to SMC bypass, fan must start at max speed.
